questions.text:
A 25-year-old student has been experiencing yellowish discoloration of the palms for the past seven months, with no changes in sclera or mucous membranes and no history of chemical exposure. His lipid profile shows the below results: Laboratory investigations: 

 

 

Total cholesterol: 240 mg/dl (N = < 200 mg/dl) 

LDL cholesterol: 145 mg/dl (N = < 100 mg/dl) 

TG: 250 mg/dl (N = 60-150 mg/dl) 

HDL cholesterol: 45 mg/dl  (N = 40-75 mg/dl) 

Lipoprotein electrophoresis shows a broad beta band. 

 

Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia

 

Explanation:

 

Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia or broad beta disease, is caused by a defect in apolipoprotein E (apoE), which impairs the clearance of chylomicron remnants and IDL from the plasma.

 

Key features include:

  • Elevated total cholesterol and triglycerides (typically both increased)
  • Broad beta band on electrophoresis, due to accumulation of remnant lipoproteins
  • Palmar xanthomas — yellowish discoloration or deposits in the creases of the palms
  • Increased risk of premature atherosclerosis

 

This patient’s lipid pattern, broad beta band, and palmar discoloration (xanthomas) are classic for Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Familial Chylomicronemia (Type I) – Presents with very high triglycerides, creamy plasma, and eruptive xanthomas, usually without a broad beta band.
  • Option C. Abetalipoproteinemia – Features very low or absent apoB-containing lipoproteins, leading to low cholesterol and triglycerides, fat malabsorption, and acanthocytosis. Not seen here.
  • Option D. Type IIa Hyperlipoproteinemia (Familial Hypercholesterolemia) – Characterized by isolated elevated LDL, normal triglycerides, and tendon xanthomas. Not compatible with this lipid profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia by its unique clinical features:

  • Combined elevation of cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Broad beta band on electrophoresis
  • Palmar xanthomas

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p245, 246.

questions.text: A physician is consulting a patient about his elevated triglyceride levels. The patient is non-diabetic and has no history of alcohol overuse, factors known to influence triglyceride levels. The physician explains that a certain lipoprotein is primarily responsible for transporting triglycerides synthesized by the liver. Which lipoprotein does the liver use to transport these endogenous triglycerides?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VLDL

 

Option B:

 

Very Low-Density Lipoproteins (VLDL) are produced by the liver and are responsible for transporting endogenous triacylglycerols, which are synthesized by the liver, to adipose tissue and muscle. VLDL serves as the body's internal transport mechanism for lipids it has produced or extracted from the diet and processed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: These transport dietary, or exogenous, lipids from the intestines to other tissues in the body after a meal.

 

Option C: LDL: Primarily carries cholesterol to the body's cells rather than triacylglycerol.

 

Option D: HDL: Involved in reverse cholesterol transport, carrying cholesterol from the tissues back to the liver, and is not a primary carrier of triacylglycerol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p 226.

questions.text: In an experiment, a team of scientists incubates liver cells at 0°C and treats them with trypsin to digest surface receptors. The temperature is then increased to 37°C, and radioactive LDL is introduced to the culture. Subsequently, the labelled LDL is found inside the liver cells. What is the process responsible for the internalization of LDL called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Receptor-mediated endocytosis

 

Option D:

 

  • The LDL is taken up by peripheral tissues in the body by receptor-mediated endocytosis.
  • LDL receptors are located in specialized regions called clathrin coated pits. ​​Binding of LDL to the apo-B100 receptor by apo B100 → the receptor-LDL complex is internalized by endocytosis → endosome vesicle fuses with lysosomes → receptor is recycled and returns to the cell surface and LDL particle + apoproteins + cholesterol ester are hydrolyzed by lysosomal hydrolases → forms fatty acids and free cholesterol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Facilitated diffusion: Is the transport of low-permeability molecules with the aid of a carrier protein.

 

Option B: Pinocytosis: Uptake of small molecules in solution, is receptor –independent.

 

Option C: Phagocytosis: Process by which cells such as macrophages and neutrophils engulf large particles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Receptor-mediated endocytosis is the specific and efficient mechanism by which LDL is internalized by liver cells, involving the interaction of LDL with cell surface LDL receptors.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 257-258.

questions.text: A molecular biologist is explaining to a group of students the unique process through which Apo B48 is produced in the body. This protein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons, which transport dietary lipids from the intestines to other parts of the body. By what mechanism is Apo B48 generated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

Option B:

 

  • Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons.
  • It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells.
  • Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein.
  • It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.  

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: RNA alternate splicing: This process involves the removal or inclusion of segments of the pre-mRNA transcript, leading to the production of different mRNA variants and, consequently, different proteins from the same gene. However, it is not the mechanism by which Apo B48 is produced.

 

Option C: DNA editing: DNA editing refers to direct changes to the DNA sequence itself, which is not applicable in the case of Apo B48 production.

 

Option D: RNA interference: RNA interference is a biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression or translation by neutralizing targeted mRNA molecules. It does not involve the production of Apo B48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apo B48 is generated through RNA editing, a post-transcriptional modification that alters the nucleotide sequence of the RNA, resulting in a shorter protein variant crucial for chylomicron formation in the intestines.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p226.

choices.text: Increasing the synthesis and secretion of VLDL from liver resulting in high LDL levels in the blood
Inhibiting the binding of apoB to LDL receptor, thereby blocking the lipoprotein uptake and increasing the blood cholesterol levels
Decreasing the availability of LDL receptors on the cell surface, resulting in decreased LDL uptake and high blood cholesterol level
Preventing the cholesterol breakdown into bile acids in the liver

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with coronary artery disease (CAD) is being successfully treated with anti-atherogenic medication that targets PCSK9. Following treatment, his lipid profile normalizes, and his cardiac status improves. What is the primary function of PCSK9?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing the availability of LDL receptors on the cell surface, resulting in decreased LDL uptake and high blood cholesterol level

 

PCSK9 (Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9) normally binds to LDL receptors and promotes their degradation in lysosomes, which prevents the receptors from being recycled back to the cell surface. This natural function of PCSK9 decreases the number of LDL receptors available on cell surfaces, especially hepatocytes, resulting in reduced LDL clearance from the bloodstream and consequently higher blood cholesterol levels.

 

Anti-atherogenic medications that target PCSK9 (PCSK9 inhibitors) work by inhibiting this protein, thereby preventing LDL receptor degradation. This leads to:

  • Increased recycling of LDL receptors back to the cell surface
  • Greater availability of LDL receptors on hepatocytes
  • Enhanced clearance of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream
  • Reduced blood LDL cholesterol levels
  • Improved cardiovascular outcomes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Increasing the synthesis and secretion of VLDL - PCSK9 does not directly affect VLDL synthesis or secretion; its primary role is related to LDL receptor regulation.

 

Option B: Inhibiting the binding of apoB to the LDL receptor - PCSK9 does not interfere with apoB binding to LDL receptors; it affects the degradation of LDL receptors themselves.

 

Option D: Preventing the breakdown of cholesterol into bile acids - PCSK9's function is not related to cholesterol metabolism into bile acids; it specifically impacts the recycling and degradation of LDL receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that PCSK9 inhibitors work by preventing PCSK9-mediated degradation of LDL receptors, thereby increasing LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL cholesterol clearance, and lowering blood cholesterol levels in patients with coronary artery disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 271, 275, 278-279.

questions.text: In a clinical study examining lipid metabolism disorders, researchers observe participants with markedly elevated plasma levels of chylomicrons and triacylglycerols. Which type of hyperlipoproteinemia is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I hyperlipoproteinemia

 

Option A:

 

  • Hyperlipoproteinemia I/Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (type I) is an autosomal recessive condition presents with fasting chylomicronemia and Hypertriacylglycerolemia due to deficiency of LPL or abnormal LPL or apo C-ll deficiency causing inactive LPL.
  • Slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL with low levels of LDL and HDL are noted.
  • C/F: Eruptive xanthoma; hepatomegaly; Pain abdomen, manifests in young age with less risk of coronary disease
  • A chylomicron band in fasting plasma is the characteristic finding of the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Familial Endogenous type - due to over production of TG by liver, elevated VLDL level → Cardiac manifestations. Associated with DM, obesity and impaired glucose tolerance.

 

Option C: Elevation of both CHL and TG with excessive production of apo-B → elevated LDL and VLDL.

 

Option D: Elevated CM and VLDL. Hypertriglyceridemia secondary to disorders like obesity, excessive alcohol intake, renal failure, pancreatitis, etc. are common. Other causes:  hepatic lipase defect, LCAT defect and Lp(a) excess and Wolman’s disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency, is characterized by markedly elevated plasma levels of chylomicrons due to a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase or its cofactor apolipoprotein C-II. This leads to an inability to hydrolyze the triglycerides carried by chylomicrons, resulting in high levels of both chylomicrons and triglycerides in the plasma.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p245, 246.

questions.text: In an electrophoretic separation procedure, a technician observes the migration of lipoproteins from the cathode (-) to the anode (+) sidewhich of the following correctly orders the lipoproteins from cathode to anode?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CM > LDL > VLDL > HDL

 

Option A:

 

Plasma lipoproteins can be separated on the basis of their electrophoretic mobility:

Those with higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with less proteins have low mobility

 

Classifcation of Lipoproteins

 

Depending on the density (by ultracentrifugation) or on the electrophoretic mobility, the lipoproteins in plasma are classified into five major types 

  1. Chylomicrons: Contain apoprotein B-48.
  2. Very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) or pre-beta lipoproteins. Main apoprotein is B-100.
  3. Intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL) or broad-beta lipoproteins
  4. Low-density lipoproteins or beta lipoproteins. Major apoprotein in LDL is B-100.
  5. High-density lipoproteins or alpha lipoproteins. Major apoprotein in HDL is apo A.

 

Separation by Ultracentrifugation

The lipoproteins are characterized on the basis of their density. Fat is less dense than water; so fat floats on water. Lipoproteins with high lipid content will have a low density and so float on centrifugation. Those with high protein content will sediment easily and have a high density. 

 

Separation by Electrophoresis

As a general rule, those with higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with fewer proteins have minimum mobility.

 

Note : pattern of electrophoresis and ultracentrifugation are different as shown in the diagram.

 

Electrophoresis 

 

Standard order from Cathode (-) to Anode (+):

CM >LDL>VLDL>HDL 

 

Ultracentrifugation: sequence is 

CM > VLDL > LDL > HDL

 

 

Comparison of electrophoretic and ultracentrifugation patterns of lipoproteins.

(VLDL: very low-density lipoproteins; IDL: intermediate density lipoproteins; LDL: low-density lipoproteins; HDL: high-density lipoproteins; FFA: free fatty acid)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipoprotein electrophoresis separates particles based on their protein content and charge. Understanding the typical migration pattern helps diagnose dyslipidemias and distinguish between different lipoprotein abnormalities.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: 228.

questions.text: Three hours after a healthy middle-aged man eats a meal that includes carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, a blood sample is drawn to assess his lipid profile. Considering normal digestive physiology and the timing of the sample in relation to his meal, which component in his blood is likely to be elevated at this point?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chylomicrons

 

Option D:

 

  • After a well-balanced meal , the products of digestion such as glucose, amino acids, triacylglycerols are packaged as chylomicrons from the intestine and VLDL from the liver enter the bloodstream

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fatty acids: Fatty acids in the blood usually increase during fasting when fat stores are mobilized for energy, not postprandially.

 

Option B: Glucagon: Glucagon levels typically rise during fasting to promote glucose production and release by the liver, not after a meal when insulin is the predominant hormone.

 

Option C: Glycerol: Glycerol levels in the blood typically increase during triglyceride breakdown, which occurs during fasting or exercise, not postprandially.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The postprandial rise in chylomicron levels in response to a well-balanced meal, reflecting the normal physiological process of dietary fat transport.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 257-259.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a familial history of increased cholesterol levels presents with an isolated elevation in LDL. His father and brother had similar lipid abnormalities. Given the isolated increase in LDL and family history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor mutation

 

Option C:

 

  • Lipoproteinemia are categorized by Frederickson's Classification
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) results in severe hypercholesterolemia associated with premature atherosclerosis.
  • The defect is in the gene for the LDL receptor or mutation in the ligand region of apo B100 → so, LDL is not cleared from the blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Familial type llI hyperlipoproteinemia: due to the abnormality in apoE , remnant clearance by the liver is defective resulting in increased levels of chylomicron and VLDL remnants. It can cause hypercholesterolemia, atherosclerosis, and xanthomas.

 

Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia: Defective loading of apo B with lipid → absence of formation of chylomicrons, VLDL or LDL, low blood acylglycerols with accumulation of it in the intestine and liver.

 

Option D: Familial LPL deficiency (type l): Due to deficiency of LPL or abnormal LPL or apo C-ll deficiency →  Hypertriacylglycerolemia with slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, low levels of LDL and HDL.

 

Educational objective:

 

LDL receptor gene mutation is characterized by isolated elevated LDL cholesterol levels and a family history of hypercholesterolemia and early cardiovascular disease.
 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 275,276.

questions.text: Based on the clinical presentation (as shown in image), which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial Hypercholesterolemia

 

Option B:

 

  • The deposition of lipids in subcutaneous tissue leads to xanthomas.
  • Xanthelasma are lipid deposits under the periorbital skin and contain mainly cholesterol.
  • Tendinous xanthoma are found over the tendons.
  • Deposits of lipids in cornea lead to corneal arcus; indicating hypercholesterolemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Familial Chylomicronemia: C/F- Hepatomegaly, eruptive xanthoma and abdominal pain.

 

Option C: Abetalipoproteinemia: Low levels of serum triglycerides, cholesterol and phospholipids. C/F- Blindness due to degenerative changes in retina and spiny projections in erythrocytes (acanthocytes).

 

Option D: Broad Beta Disease: Palmar xanthoma and increased risk for vascular disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

Familial Hypercholesterolemia is characterized by high LDL cholesterol levels and the presence of xanthomas, which are deposits of cholesterol in the skin and tendons, due to a genetic defect in LDL receptors.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: P245, 246.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man who consumes a fat-free, high-carbohydrate diet finds that he continues to gain weight. Considering the dietary influence on lipoprotein metabolism, which apoprotein is most likely to be elevated in his blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) VLDL

 

Option D:

 

  • Excess Carbohydrates in the body are converted to Acetyl CoA. These are then converted to Fatty acid, which gets esterified to form Endogenous TGs.
  • VLDL is the carrier of endogenous TGs. So, blood VLDL level is raised.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: Carry TAG from gut to muscle and adipose tissue

 

Option B: HDL: Carry cholesterol from peripheral tissues to liver

 

Option C: LDL: Carry cholesterol from liver to peripheral tissues

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fat-free, high-carbohydrate diet can lead to increased synthesis of VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) in the liver. VLDL is responsible for transporting endogenously synthesized triglycerides, which the body produces from excess carbohydrates, to adipose tissue for storage. This could contribute to ongoing obesity despite the absence of dietary fat.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 255-257.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease (CAD), currently undergoing treatment, is advised to implement lifestyle modifications and monitor his lipid profile quarterly. Among the lipoproteins evaluated, which one is characterized by the lowest lipid-to-protein ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HDL

 

Option C:

 

High-density lipoprotein (HDL) is known for having the highest protein content relative to its lipid content among the various lipoproteins, resulting in the lowest lipid-to-protein ratio. This high protein content contributes to HDL's denser nature compared to other lipoproteins and its role in reverse cholesterol transport, where it facilitates the removal of excess cholesterol from cells and atheromatous plaques in the arteries, transporting it back to the liver for excretion or recycling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: These are the largest lipoproteins with the highest lipid content, primarily triglycerides, thus having a high lipid-to-protein ratio.

 

Option B: VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein): VLDL particles are rich in triglycerides and have a higher lipid-to-protein ratio compared to HDL but lower than chylomicrons.

 

Option D: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein): LDL carries mostly cholesterol and has a lower lipid-to-protein ratio than VLDL and chylomicrons but higher than HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Among different HDL particles, percentage of lipids seen will be:  

 

HDL1 : 65%

 

HDL2  : 67%

 

HDL3  : 43%

 

Preβ-HDL : 30

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 478-479, 484.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes routine health screening, including a lipid profile, while fasting. Her results show a total cholesterol of 300 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol of 25 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 150 mg/dL. Utilizing the Friedewald equation to assess her cardiovascular risk, what is the LDL cholesterol level in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 245 mg/dl

 

Option A:

 

  • The total blood cholesterol in the fasting state is equal to the sum of the cholesterol in LDL + cholesterol in HDL + cholesterol in VLDLs.
  • This last term is calculated by dividing the triacylglycerol value by 5 because cholesterol accounts for about 1/5 of the volume of VLDL in fasted blood.
  • 300 = LDL cholesterol + 25+150/5
  • LDL cholesterol = 300-55= 245 mg/dl.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Friedewald equation, used to estimate the level of LDL cholesterol, is LDL = Total Cholesterol - HDL - (Triglycerides / 5).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9/e: p241, 242, Lippincott 7/e: p 244

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a two-year history of gradually declining cognitive function. PET imaging reveals widespread amyloid deposition, notably in the striatum. Considering the role of apolipoproteins in Alzheimer's disease pathology, which apolipoprotein variant is most closely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) APOE4

 

Option C:

 

  • Familial AD and Apo-E4 gene: There is an association between patients possessing the apo E4 allele and the incidence of Alzheimer disease.
  • Apparently, apo E4 binds more avidly to β-amyloid found in neuritic plaques.
  • Genes identified with AD are that coding for APP, presenilin-1 (chromosome 14), presenilin-2 (chromosome 1) or AD3 (chromosome 14) or AD4 (chromosome 1), and Apo-E4 gene (chromosome 19).
  • The presence of Apo-E4 gene is the major risk factor for AD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: APOE3: This is the most common allele of APOE and is considered neutral in terms of Alzheimer's risk.

 

Option B: APOE1: This is not a commonly recognized allele in the context of Alzheimer's disease risk.

 

Option D: APOE2: This allele is considered to have a protective effect against Alzheimer's disease, associated with a lower risk of developing the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

APOE4 is a genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, associated with increased amyloid deposition in the brain and an elevated risk of developing the disease, particularly at an earlier age.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 46, 275.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a sedentary lifestyle presents with abdominal pain. An ultrasound reveals hepatomegaly, and his lipid profile, characterized by a creamy layer over clear plasma 24 hours after collection, indicates elevated triglycerides and cholesterol levels. He is diagnosed with Type I hyperlipoproteinemia. Which of the following is a hallmark feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevated chylomicrons

 

Option D:

 

  • Hyperlipoproteinemia I/Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (type I) is an autosomal recessive condition presents with fasting chylomicronemia and Hypertriacylglycerolemia due to deficiency of LPL or abnormal LPL or apo C-ll deficiency causing inactive LPL.
  • Slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL with low levels of LDL and HDL are noted.
  • C/F: Eruptive xanthoma; hepatomegaly; Pain abdomen, manifests in young age with less risk of coronary disease.
  • A chylomicron band in fasting plasma is the characteristic finding of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Elevated LDL: Seen in type IIA and IIB and low levels in type I Hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Option B: Elevated HDL: Low levels of HDL in type I due to slow clearance.

 

Option C: Elevated lipoprotein lipase: In type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, lipoprotein lipase is deficient and not elevated as given in the option.

 

Educational objective:

 

Identify Type I hyperlipoproteinemia by the presence of elevated chylomicrons, leading to high plasma triglyceride levels and the characteristic appearance of a lipid profile sample after standing, indicative of this condition's impact on lipid metabolism.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 275.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman reports having yellowish, soft lesions at the inner corners of the upper eyelids on both eyes for the past three years. Recently, she has noticed an increase in their size. Based on the described location and appearance of the lesions, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Xanthelasma palpebrarum

 

Option A:

 

  • The diagnosis of the patient is Familial hypercholesterolemia.
  • In this there is defect is in LDL receptor or mutation in the ligand region of apo B100 → so, LDL is not cleared from the blood deposition of lipids in subcutaneous tissue → leads to xanthomas, seen over tendons known as Tendinous xanthoma.
  • Xanthelasma are lipid deposits under the periorbital skin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Xanthoma: While xanthomas are also lipid deposits in the skin, they can occur in various parts of the body, not specifically on the eyelids. Xanthelasma is a type of xanthoma that specifically occurs on the eyelids.

 

Option C: Arcus senilis: This is a gray or white arc visible above and below the outer part of the cornea, not on the eyelids, and it's typically associated with aging or high cholesterol.

 

Option D: Tendinous xanthoma: These are lipid deposits found in tendons, particularly the Achilles tendon, not on the eyelids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xanthelasma palpebrarum is soft, yellowish plaques on the eyelids, indicative of lipid deposition in the skin, which may suggest underlying hyperlipidemia but can also occur in individuals with normal lipid profiles.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: P245, 246.

questions.text: Which human plasma lipoprotein has the highest percentage of triacylglycerol (TAG) by weight?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chylomicron

 

Option B:

 

Chylomicrons are the lipoprotein particles that contain the highest percentage of triacylglycerol (TAG) by weight. They are responsible for transporting dietary lipids, predominantly triglycerides, from the intestines to other parts of the body for metabolism or storage. Due to their high TAG content, chylomicrons are the least dense of the lipoproteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: VLDL: Very Low-Density Lipoproteins (VLDL) carry endogenously synthesized triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues but have a lower percentage of triglycerides compared to chylomicrons.

 

Option C: HDL: High-Density Lipoproteins (HDL) are involved in reverse cholesterol transport and contain the least amount of triglycerides among the options listed.

 

Option D: LDL: Low-Density Lipoproteins (LDL) primarily carry cholesterol and have a lower percentage of triglycerides compared to VLDL and chylomicrons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HDL – High protein , Phospholipid
  • LDL – High CHL , CHL Esters
  • CM- High TAG (80%)
  • VLDL - TAG (50%)

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed, pg 254

questions.text: Which lipoprotein is predominantly involved in delivering cholesterol to the tissues?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) 

 

Option B:

 

  • The uptake of exogenous cholesterol by cells results in a marked suppression of endogenous cholesterol synthesis.
  • Low-density human lipoprotein not only contains the greatest ratio of bound cholesterol to protein but also has the greatest potency in suppressing endogenous cholesterogenesis.
  • LDLs normally suppress cholesterol synthesis by binding to a specific membrane receptor that mediates inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) coenzyme A reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Transport of TAG from liver to muscle and adipose tissue. Cholesterol composition 20 %

 

Option C: Transports Cholesterol from peripheral tissues to liver. Cholesterol 10-30%

 

Option D: Transports FFA from adipose Tissue to muscle and liver. Free fatty acids are seen in circulation, weakly bound to albumin. Cholesterol 0%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) are recognized as the primary carriers of cholesterol in the bloodstream, delivering cholesterol to various tissues for use in cell membranes and other functions. LDLs bind to specific LDL receptors on cell surfaces, facilitating the uptake of cholesterol into cells.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/ed: p225.

questions.text: A clinician is treating a patient presenting with tendon xanthomas, elevated LDL levels, and high serum cholesterol. The patient has been prescribed lovastatin, a cholesterol-lowering medication. Based on these clinical features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

Option C:

 

  • The clinical & lab features are suggestive of Familial hypercholesterolemia.
  • The defect is in the gene for the LDL receptor or mutation in the ligand region of apo B100 → so LDL is not cleared from the blood.
  • C/F: The deposition of lipids in subcutaneous tissue leads to xanthomas, seen over tendons known as Tendinous xanthoma.
  • Xanthelasma are lipid deposits under the periorbital skin.
  • Deposits of lipids in cornea lead to corneal arcus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: LPL deficiency: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency leads to elevated chylomicrons, causing high triglycerides but not typically resulting in high LDL or tendon xanthomas.

 

Option B: Tangier disease: Characterized by very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and can lead to the deposition of cholesterol in tissues, but it does not typically present with elevated LDL levels and tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D: Abetalipoproteinemia: A rare condition characterized by the absence of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins, leading to fat malabsorption and neurological symptoms, not high LDL or cholesterol levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation and appropriate treatment for familial hypercholesterolemia, includes high LDL cholesterol, tendon xanthomas, and the use of statin medications like lovastatin to lower cholesterol levels.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p245, 246.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with abdominal pain is found to have hepatomegaly via ultrasound. On examination, he exhibits skin findings as shown in the image, with a blood sample that appears creamy and shows elevated triglycerides levels. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Familial Hyper Chylomicronemia

 

Explanation:

 

Familial Hyper Chylomicronemia Syndrome (also known as Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency or dysfunction, or by apo C-II deficiency, which is a necessary cofactor for LPL activation.

 

Key clinical features:

  • Eruptive xanthomas (small, yellow papules, especially on the buttocks or extensor surfaces)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Recurrent abdominal pain (may be related to pancreatitis)
  • Milky or creamy plasma appearance
  • Very high serum triglyceride levels, often >1000 mg/dL

Although this condition typically presents in childhood or adolescence, adult presentations can occur, especially if the diagnosis is delayed or partial enzyme activity exists.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Broad Beta Disease (Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia) – Associated with palmar xanthomas and elevated remnants. Presents with increased cardiovascular risk.
  • Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia – Features very low serum triglycerides and cholesterol, acanthocytosis, fat malabsorption, and retinal degeneration. Plasma is not creamy.
  • Option D: Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Type IIa) – Caused by LDL receptor mutations, presents with tendinous xanthomas, corneal arcus, and very high LDL cholesterol levels. Triglycerides are usually normal.

 

Educational Objective:


Recognize Familial Chylomicronemia Syndrome by:

  • Eruptive xanthomas
  • Creamy plasma with markedly elevated triglycerides

It reflects a defect in chylomicron clearance, due to LPL enzyme deficiency or its apo C-II cofactor, resulting in accumulation of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins in plasma.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 275.

questions.text: A physician is advising a patient on target LDL cholesterol levels for optimal cardiovascular health. what is the recommended upper limit for LDL cholesterol in mg/dl?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100

 

Explanation:

 

For optimal cardiovascular health, particularly in primary prevention (patients without existing cardiovascular disease), the recommended upper limit for LDL cholesterol is typically ≤100 mg/dL.

 

Key guidelines (such as those from the American Heart Association and NCEP ATP III) suggest:

  • <100 mg/dL: Optimal LDL level
  • 100–129 mg/dL: Near or above optimal
  • 130–159 mg/dL: Borderline high
  • 160–189 mg/dL: High
  • ≥190 mg/dL: Very high

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. 130 mg/dL: This is considered borderline high for LDL, not the optimal upper limit.
  • Option C. 75 mg/dL: it’s below the general upper limit for most patients.
  • Option D. 50 mg/dL: Not a standard upper limit; too low for general recommendation.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  • Understand that <100 mg/dL is the widely recommended upper limit for LDL cholesterol in general cardiovascular prevention.

questions.text: During a clinical discussion on the diagnostic significance of various lipoproteins, a medical instructor inquires about the clinical condition associated with elevated levels of Lipoprotein X. Which condition is indicated by the presence of Lipoprotein X?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholestasis

 

Option B:

 

  • In cholestasis, free cholesterol combines with phospholipids and secreted into plasma as a constituent of a lamellar particle called LP- X → gets deposited in skinfolds → producing lesions resembling those in FDBL.
  • Plantar and eruptive xanthomas are also seen in patients with cholestasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Atherosclerosis: While atherosclerosis involves lipid accumulation, Lipoprotein X is not a specific indicator for this condition. Traditional lipoproteins like LDL and HDL are more closely related to atherosclerotic risk.

 

Option C: Myocardial Infarction (MI): Lipoprotein X is not a biomarker for MI. Cardiac troponins and other markers like CK-MB are used to diagnose myocardial infarction.

 

Option D: Hepatitis: Hepatitis refers to inflammation of the liver, which can be due to viral infections or other causes. Elevated Lipoprotein X is not a specific marker for hepatitis, although liver function tests may show abnormalities in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipoprotein X is an abnormal lipoprotein that is often present in the plasma of patients with cholestasis, a condition characterized by impaired bile flow. The accumulation of lipids that are normally excreted in bile leads to the formation of this atypical lipoprotein. Its detection can serve as an indicator of cholestatic liver disease.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p 229.
